summary: First mandatory recycling law in the nation	 enacted 1987. Provides framework for statewide recycling requirements.
key_provisions: Mandated recycling in all 564 municipalities; 21 counties required to include recyclables in county plans; created municipal tonnage grants program ($22M/year); 10% to education
connection_to_hearing: Gary Sondermeyer cited this as foundational. Said current NJ system handles 127	000 tons plastics/year

summary: First extended producer responsibility law in NJ	 predating mandatory recycling. Addresses all litter	 not just bottles.
key_provisions: Litter-producing industries pay for cleanup; funds anti-litter efforts statewide
connection_to_hearing: Sondermeyer called this "NJs first extended producer responsibility law 38 years ago"

summary: Requires minimum recycled content in plastic products sold in NJ. Initial targets began January 18	 2024.
key_provisions: Sets minimum recycled content percentages for plastic products
connection_to_hearing: Sondermeyer: "most important piece of recycling legislation since the mandatory law"

summary: Created council to study and recommend improvements to NJs recycling infrastructure.
key_provisions: 15 specific recommendations in April 2022 report including: statewide recycling education	 uniform recyclables list	 truth in labeling	 financial assistance programs	 EPR
connection_to_hearing: Multiple speakers referenced this. Sondermeyer said recommendations still need implementation

summary: Banned single-use plastic bags at retail establishments.
key_provisions: Prohibited single-use plastic bags; required reusable bags
connection_to_hearing: Multiple speakers referenced as successful example of behavior change legislation

summary: First state to require climate education K-12 in schools.
key_provisions: Mandatory climate curriculum in all grade levels
connection_to_hearing: Sondermeyer cited as platform to integrate recycling/composting education

summary: Shift financial and legal responsibility for packaging waste from taxpayers to producers.
key_provisions: Would require producers to fund recycling/disposal of their packaging; shift costs from municipalities
connection_to_hearing: Both Sondermeyer (ANJR supports) and Enck (Beyond Plastics) strongly recommended; emphasized needs-assessment component

summary: Refundable deposit on beverage containers to increase recycling rates and reduce litter.
key_provisions: 5-10 cent deposit on bottles/cans; reverse vending machines; redemption centers; refillable container provisions
connection_to_hearing: Judith Enck strongly recommended; ANJR (Sondermeyer) opposed	 saying it would undermine existing infrastructure

summary: Mandatory reduction in plastic packaging over 10 years with glide path.
key_provisions: 10% reduction in 2 years; 20% in 4 years; eventual 50% total reduction; environmental standards for packaging
connection_to_hearing: Enck: "fuel efficiency standards for packaging" - strongest recommendation

summary: Single statewide list of what is recyclable to reduce confusion.
key_provisions: Replace 21 county lists with one uniform list; models from Colorado	 Oregon	 Connecticut
connection_to_hearing: Sondermeyer said ANJR working on this; could be voluntary like Connecticut

summary: Prohibit chemical recycling from counting as recycling; restrict taxpayer subsidies.
key_provisions: Ban pyrolysis facilities from being classified as manufacturing; prevent taxpayer subsidies; restrict chemical recycling claims
connection_to_hearing: Enck strongly opposed chemical recycling - "1.3% of plastic	 been failing since the 80s"

summary: Expand existing bans to include polystyrene and other problematic plastics.
key_provisions: Ban polystyrene containers statewide; expand restrictions on difficult-to-recycle plastics
connection_to_hearing: Mentioned in context of California EPR negotiations

summary: Address NJ being #2 plastic exporter in US.
key_provisions: Restrict export of plastic waste to countries without recycling infrastructure
connection_to_hearing: Enck flagged NJ as #2 exporter after California; referenced PBS Frontline "Plastic Wars"
